FacilityName: San Jose Creek Water Reclamation Plant

OperatorName: County Sanitation Dist of LA County
SafetyInspectionBy: Los Angeles County Fire Department & US EPA

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The County Sanitation Districts of Los Angeles County (CSDLAC) owns and operates the San Jose Creek Water Reclamation Plant (SJCWRP).  The SJCWRP is located on two sites designated as the SJCWRP East and SJCWRP West.



The SJCWRP East is located at 1965 Workman Mill Road in Whittier, California 90601, and stores a maximum of 72,000-pounds of chlorine at any one time (contained in two 25-ton bulk storage containers located indoors), a maximum of 68,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide at any one time (contained in two 20-ton bulk storage containers located indoors), and a maximum of 130,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia (19.5 percent concentration) at any one time (contained in three 6,180 gallon above-ground tanks located outdoors). 



The SJCWRP West is located at 1971 Workman Mill Road in Whittier, California 90601, and stores a maximum of 72,000-pounds of chlorine at any one time (contained in two 25-ton bulk storage containers located indoors), a maximum of 68,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide at any one time (contained in two 20-ton bulk storage containers located indoors), and a maximum of 85,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia (19.5% concentration) at any one time (contained in two 6,180-gallon above-ground tanks located outdoors).   



Due to the quantities of chlorine, sulfur dioxide and aqueous ammonia stored, handled and used at the site, SJCWRP is subject to requirements specified in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (US EPA's) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations (Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68), the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulations (California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Articles 1 through 11), and the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations (29 CFR Part 1910.119).

  

GENERAL FACILITY INFORMATION 



The primary operation conducted at the SJCWRP is the treatment of wastewater (NAICS Code 22132 - Sewa

ge Treatment Facilities).  The treatment facilities are located on a land area of approximately 39 acres, bounded on the southwest by the Pomona (60) Freeway, on the southeast side by Workman Mill Road, on the northeast side by the San Jose Creek Channel, and on the northwest side by the San Gabriel River.  



CSDLAC has operated the SJCWRP facility since inception in 1971.  The design treatment capacity of the plant has increased in stages, from an original capacity of 37.5 million gallons of wastewater per day (mgd) to the current capacity of 100 mgd.  The wastewater treated at SJCWRP originates mainly from approximately 1,000,000 domestic users in the San Gabriel Valley region; a small fraction is of industrial origin.  Wastewater treatment utilizes the activated sludge process with aqueous ammonia addition, chlorination, and dechlorination to yield a tertiary effluent that is suitable for re-use.  Aqueous ammonia (19.5% concentration) is used in the disinfection process. 

 

RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY COMPONENTS



Storing and handling large quantities of aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide can create hazardous situations.  For this reason, SJCWRP follows all industry recommended practices for safely storing and handling these chemicals.  SJCWRP's aqueous ammonia handling processes are subject to the CalARP Program Level 2 Requirements.  SJCWRP's chlorine and sulfur dioxide handling processes are subject to the US EPA RMP and to the CalARP Program Level 3 requirements.  These programs require a summary in the RMP of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility, including a description of the possible consequences in case of an accident and the actions which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.  The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 

  ? Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.

  ? General facility and regulated substances information.

  ? Offsite c

onsequence analysis results. 

  ? Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.

  ? Five-year accident history summary.

  ? Emergency response program summary.

  ? Planned changes to improve safety.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES



CSDLAC's accidental release prevention policy at SJCWRP involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of California and EPA's Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  



The CSDLAC emergency response policy involves the preparation of Hazardous Materials and Hazardous Waste Consolidated Contingency Plans (HMHWCCP) for handling hazardous materials which are specific for each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA and CalARP Program Emergency Response Program requirements.  The CSDLAC has prepared a HMHWCCP for the SJCWRP for storing and handling hazardous materials, including aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The HMHWCCP has been coordinated with the local response agency, the County of Los Angeles Fire Department (LACFD).  The SJCWRP has an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



Aqueous ammonia (19.5% concentration) is used to maintain the disinfection limits in the treated effluent.  The aqueous ammonia is provided by delivery truck and transferred via hose to the ammonia storage tanks.  The aqueous ammonia solution is stored in 30 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) design, American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) Code unfired pressure vessels

.  There are three 6,180-gallon tanks at SJCWRP East and two 6,180-gallon tanks at SJCWRP West.  The working capacity of each tank is 5,120 gallons, and each tank is provided with a high level alarm, pressure relief valves, and secondary containment.  The aqueous ammonia is then transferred from the storage tanks to dosing locations within the effluent channel and mixed.  Once the aqueous ammonia is mixed with the treated effluent, CalARP regulations no longer apply.



Chlorine used for chlorination at SJCWRP and is received in chlorine trailers and transferred to bulk storage tanks located inside the buildings.  Sulfur dioxide used for dechlorination is also received at SJCWRP in sulfur dioxide trailers and transferred to storage tanks located inside the buildings.  The chlorination systems at SJCWRP consist of two chlorine bulk storage tanks, evaporators, chlorinators, residual analyzers, ejectors, diffusers, chlorine contact tanks, piping and other equipment.  The capacity of each chlorine bulk storage tank is 25 tons; however, the maximum quantity of chlorine present in a tank at any given time is only 18 tons.  In case of a major chlorine leak, the bulk storage tanks and the chlorine tank trailer can be isolated by the emergency shutoff valves located on the piping downstream of the bulk storage tank manway and at the end of the flexible hoses that connect to the tank trailer.  There are emergency shutdown switches (push buttons) located outside each door into the chlorine building, and on the chlorine shutdown (emergency) valve control panel located on the mezzanine of the chlorine transfer area.  On the chlorine shutdown (emergency) valve control panel, there are individual control switches for each valve.  All emergency shutdown valves can also be activated from the Plant Control Room. 



Chlorine gas detectors are used to detect a chlorine leak in the bulk storage and chlorinator rooms.  Upon detection of approximately 0.5 parts per millions by volume (pp

mv) chlorine, the detectors will send a signal which will shut down the normal ventilation system to contain the chlorine gas within the chlorination and storage rooms.  The caustic scrubber system is automatically activated in the event of a chlorine leak.



The sulfur dioxide systems at SJCWRP consist of two sulfur dioxide bulk storage tanks, evaporators, sulfonators, residual analyzers, ejectors, diffusers, and piping and other equipment.  The capacity of each sulfur dioxide bulk storage tank is 20 tons; however, the maximum quantity of sulfur dioxide present in a tank at any given time is only 17 tons.  In case of a major sulfur dioxide leak, the bulk storage tanks and the sulfur dioxide tank trailer can be isolated by the emergency shutoff valves located on the piping downstream of the bulk storage tank manway.  In addition, emergency shutoff valves are located at the end of each of the flexible hoses that connect to the tank trailer at SJCWRP East, and at the end of the sulfur dioxide gas and airpad flexible hoses at SJCWRP West.  Installation of another emergency shutoff valve, located at the end of the sulfur dioxide liquid hose that connects to the tank trailer at SJCWRP West, was completed by August 1999.  Similar to the chlorine system, there are emergency shutdown switches on the sulfur dioxide system.



Sulfur dioxide gas detectors are used to detect a sulfur dioxide leak in the bulk storage room and sulfonator room.  Upon detection of approximately 5 ppmv sulfur dioxide, the detectors will send a signal, which will shut down the normal ventilation system to contain the gas within the sulfonator and storage room.  The caustic scrubber system is automatically activated in the event of a sulfur dioxide leak.



The scrubber systems at both plants are equipped with emergency generator sets.  The emergency generator will automatically start powering in the event of a power failure and will continue to run for 5 minutes after regular power is restored.  Th

e emergency generator powers the entire scrubbing system including, local alarms, the scrubber fan (SJCWRP East only), caustic recirculation pumps, electrically-operated valves and the sump pump.  The generator also powers portions of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems including the automatic shutoff valve system (including the air compressors), lighting in both areas as well as lighting in the scrubber area, gas detectors, and the building ventilation fans. 



SJCWRP East is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through a normally closed security gate with a guard shack and closed-circuit television on the main gate entrance, which is closed after regular hours.  SJCWRP West is manned 8 hours per day, and during the other 16 hours per day, alarms are answered by the SJCWRP East operators.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary



Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst case analysis has been defined for each covered process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook.  A list of scenarios is in Table 1 below.  Both facilities have the same scenarios for each chemical.



TABLE 1: SJCWRP EAST AND WEST WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS

  RELEASE SCENARIO            CHEMICAL    TYPE OF RELEASE

  Worst-Case Scenario (OCA 1)    Aqueous Ammonia    Instantaneous release from largest storage tank/vessel on-site.

  Worst-case Scenario (OCA 3)    Chlorine    Instantaneous release from largest storage tank/vessel on-site.

  Worst-case Scenario (OCA 5)    Sulfur Dioxide    Instantaneous release from largest storage tank/vessel on-site.



Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary



Three alternative case release scenarios were modeled, one for each covered chemical.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance W

orkbook. A list of scenarios is in Table 2 below.  Both facilities have the same scenarios for each chemical.

 

TABLE 2: SJCWRP EAST AND WEST ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

  RELEASE SCENARIO            CHEMICAL    TYPE OF RELEASE

  Alternative Release (OCA 2)    Aqueous Ammonia    Ammonia truck transfer.

  Alternative Release (OCA 4)    Chlorine    Flexible hose release

  Alternative Release (OCA 6)    Sulfur Dioxide    Flexible hose release



RISK CONSIDERATIONS



Although the use of chlorine, sulfur dioxide, and aqueous ammonia for the water reclamation process has inherent potential risks, and worst case release scenarios can potentially reach the community, SJCWRP has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.



SJCWRP is in compliance with Federal and State PSM requirements.  SJCWRP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements: 

  ? Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.

  ? Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.

  ? Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.

  ? Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.

  ? Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.

  ? Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.

  ? High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.

  ? Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.



Chemical-specific prevention steps include the awareness of the hazardous and toxic propertie

s of aqueous ammonia and the remotely-controlled shutoff valves on the ammonia transfer trucks.  Chemical-specific prevention steps include the use of supplied air respirators (SAR) and self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine/sulfur dioxide supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine/sulfur dioxide, presence of chlorine/sulfur dioxide detectors and alarms, remotely-controlled shutoff valves, and chlorine/sulfur dioxide scrubbers. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by SJCWRP to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine, sulfur dioxide, and aqueous ammonia.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  



The Prevention Program (Program Level 2 and Level 3) elements include:

  ? Safety Information/Process Safety Information,

  ? Hazard Review/Process Hazard Analysis,

  ? Operating Procedures,

  ? Training,

  ? Mechanical Integrity,

  ? Management of Change,

  ? Pre-Startup Safety Review,

  ? Compliance Audits,

  ? Incident Investigation,

  ? Employee Participation,

  ? Hot Work Permit, and 

  ? Contractors.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The accident history can be found in the documentation located behind the Incident Investigation Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook.  No reportable accidents have occurred at the SJCWRP facilities in the last five years, since 2009.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



SJCWRP-trained operators are first responders to aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide leak alarms and accidental releases.  Operators from SJCWRP East respond to accidental releases at SJCWRP West when operators are not present after hours.  Depending on the severity of the

accidental release, external resources such as the LACFD will be called upon to aid in handling an aqueous ammonia, chlorine, or sulfur dioxide release.  As part of the emergency response program, CSDLAC has developed and implemented HMHWCCPs for both facilities for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment.  The HMHWCCPs have been coordinated with the local response agency (LACFD).  The main elements of each emergency response plan are: (1) initial discovery equipment and procedure, (2) response to an emergency, including procedures for immediate action and internal notifications, (3) procedures for external notifications, including coordination with Local Governments, Incident Commanders, (4) incident action plan, including mitigation actions, response resources, (5) implementation of tactical plan, and (6) termination and follow-up actions. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



In 1990, as part of its compliance with the California Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP), numerous changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified for the storage, handling and use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide as part of the PHAs conducted at the SJCWRP.  The PHAs conducted in 1990 were reviewed in 1997 under the RMPP and PSM Program as part of an update.  In 1999, as part of its compliance with the US EPA RMP and California RMP programs CSDLAC conducted PHA updates for the storage, handling and use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at SJCWRP.  Furthermore, in 2004 and 2009, CSDLAC conducted a PHA on the storage, handling and use of aqueous ammonia at SJCWRP.  ALL recommended actions resulting from these PHAs and PHA Updates have been implemented as required.  



As part of the 2014 Five-Year RMP Update and Revalidation, PHA updates were conducted for the storage, handling and use of chlorine, sulfur dioxide and aqueous ammonia.  Based on this review, additional recommended actions have been identified to further improve the safety of chlor

ine, sulfur dioxide systems and aqueous ammonia storage, handling and use systems.  The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of these systems.



CSDLAC has initiated preliminary design for the conversion of the existing chlorine and sulfur dioxide chemical facilities at SJCWRP East and SJCWRP West to sodium hypochlorite and sodium bisulfite chemical facilities.  The emergency caustic scrubbers at each facility shall also be decommissioned as part of each project.  This project is expected to be completed by the next submission date in 2019.



FLAMMABLES: WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE CASE



The use of flammable materials at SJCWRP is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 



EXTERNAL EVENTS ASSESSMENT



Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.7(q), the general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of ammonia were addressed by the 2014 PHA and a previous Seismic Assessment.  Copies of the 2014 PHA conducted by Risk Management Professionals, and 2014 Seismic Assessment conducted by CSDLAC are available in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook.
